story_title: MS Discovers Family Connections and Ends Offending Cycle
summary: A young person who initially claimed to be from Alice Springs discovered deep family connections throughout Central Australia through Oonchiumpa's cultural guidance. This cultural reconnection led to positive family relationships and complete cessation of reoffending behavior.
full_story_content: MS stated that they were from Alice Springs on first engagement. However, after talking about their family connections, language and cultural ties the young person learnt that they had many family connections throughout Central Australia. Oonchiumpa was able to link MS with other family members. With the support of Oonchiumpa MS subsequently went on to develop close positive and meaningful relationships with these family members. MS hasn't re offended since and Oonchiumpa has been able to close their file.

story_title: On Country Experience Inspires Tourism Vision
summary: MS, who had a history of offending and was disconnected from family and cultural supports, engaged with Oonchiumpa and was rewarded with an on country trip. This experience inspired him to develop his own cultural tourism venture on his traditional country.
full_story_content: MS had a history of offending and was disconnected from family supports, culture and identity when commencing. MS had disengaged with all other service providers and was regularly on a search list as his whereabouts could not be ascertained. MS started working with Oonchiumpa and engaged really well, he was rewarded with an on country trip. While on that trip he experienced the way other Aboriginal people are establishing economic development with cultural tourism on their country. MS stated he wanted to do that with his mob and through support is now working on a similar tourism venture on his country.
impact_highlights: Successful engagement after disengaging with all other services

story_title: M Achieves Independence After Father's Passing
summary: After her father's passing, M was living in unstable accommodation with few belongings due to theft by transient adults. Through Oonchiumpa's support, she and her mother now live independently with their own accommodation and income.
full_story_content: After the passing of her father M was living in a town camp with her Aunty, occasionally travelling to Yeundumu to be with her mother. M did not have her own room or personal belongings at her Aunty's and anything she did have was often stolen by transient adults passing through. M's mother was on a 10 year wait list for housing. Since working with Oonchiumpa M and her mother are living independently, having their own accommodation, M has her own income and is actively seeking employment.

story_title: J Builds Confidence to Seek Support Independently
summary: J, who previously would never visit the Oonchiumpa office without others or staff transport, now confidently arranges her own transport to access support and spend time at the office independently.
full_story_content: J would never come into the office without being with other young people or having been picked up by Oonchiumpa staff. J now will arrange her own transport to come into the office on her own to get supports and 'hang out'.

story_title: A Transforms from Guarded to Articulate After Mother's Death
summary: After losing her mother and being left destitute, A was very guarded and disengaged for an extended period on Operation Luna. Since working with Oonchiumpa, she has become forthcoming about her needs and actively seeks support when needed.
full_story_content: A's mother passed away and she was left destitute living between multiple family homes with no involvement from her father. A had been on Operation Luna for an extended period of time. A was very guarded and lacked engagement. Since working with Oonchiumpa A is very forthcoming with her needs and wants, often seeking out support and assistance when needed. Other services have noted the engagement of A and several other young people when with Oonchiumpa. In particular Oonchiumpa has been called to come into school to support A (and other young people) to engage.

story_title: CB Embraces Cultural Leadership Role After Becoming a Man
summary: CB underwent traditional ceremonies to become a man and now understands his cultural responsibilities as a leader and role model in the town camp. He can reflect on past actions with remorse and sees himself as a cultural leader.
full_story_content: CB understands since becoming a man he has more responsibility and is now becoming more a of role model and leader in the Town Camp. He didn't understand the importance of his cultural role before. He is now able to reflect on his actions in the past and feeling remorse. He knows he can be a leader.
impact_highlights: Ability to reflect with remorse on past actions

story_title: Atnarpa Homestead Cultural Exchange for Girls
summary: Katrina took young girls to Atnarpa Homestead to participate in an on country program with traditional owners, providing insight into how young traditional owners work on their country and inspiring the girls to want similar programs on their own country.
full_story_content: On the 3 July Katrina took the young girls out to Atnarpa Homestead and Campground to be apart of the on country program with the traditional owners of Atnarpa. This was an opportunity to share an insight of what the young traditional owners are doing on their country working and share their cultural and land with the many interstate students apart of the Red Earth social enterprise. These two young are Luritja country and to be welcomed on eastern Arrernte country by young traditional owners was a privilege. This type of insight gives our young people the strength to be able to want to a part of similar program on their country.
impact_highlights: Inspiration for future programs on own country
Connection with young traditional owner role models

story_title: Malachi's Journey to Cultural Identity and Empowerment
summary: Malachi, who was teased by other young people for having 'no culture' due to his light skin, was supported to reconnect with his family's cultural heritage. He subsequently returned to country and demonstrated cultural knowledge sharing with non-Indigenous students.
full_story_content: Since having discussions while on country when we went on a field trip to Atnarpa station, where we spoke of learning of self-identity. Malachi had been teased by the other clients of having no culture no language because of his light skin, he looked disempowered over their remarks, I questioned them 'just because you know language does it make you more Aboriginal than him'. 1 of the question I had asked of these 2 individuals is 'what do you know of your lineage family line', 'since you're an initiated young man do you know your skin names or your own story lines'. I told Malachi it's not too late to learn these things of your family background and connection to country, I told him he's in the best position of going back to learn these things because off he's family. Malachi has family that have started to reconnect back to country by opening their own school to teach the next generation of a language that was on the brink of extinction. Malachi had returned onto country with extended family members and demonstrated sharing with non-indigenous students that recently visited he's homelands which I think is an improvement of his behaviour, he wanted to learn he wanted to be a part of knowledge sharing to him so he can be more empowered. This is cultural significance of how he has demonstrated and the empowerment of strong family culture connections on country.

story_title: School Holiday Pottery and Beauty Programs Build Confidence
summary: During September 2024 school holidays, Oonchiumpa provided various cultural and creative activities including pottery lessons with Tahlia and beauty sessions with ENDORTA, helping young people build confidence and pride in their appearance.
full_story_content: On Tuesday the 24th of September apart of the Oonchiumpa holiday program. Oonchiumpa staff picked up Bonika, Latarna and Tyereesa, Jonkia and Kayana up from Anthepe. All girls participated in our holiday programs we booked with Tahlia who has her own Arts & Craft course. The lesson today was pottery making, the girls learnt how to make bowls, shape and join the clay. The girls really enjoyed this session as it was relaxing and gave them an opportunity to sit in silence and feel the clay through hands. They enjoyed the session, and we will book future sessions with Tahlia. On Wednesday the 25th of September apart of the Oonchiumpa holiday program. Oonchiumpa staff picked up Latarna and Tyereesa, both girls participated in one of our holiday programs we booked with Endorta Beauty Salon. The session was all about feeling confident and having pride in their appearance, both girls had their nails done. This was an experience for the girls and really enjoyed themselves.
impact_highlights: Provided relaxing creative outlet through pottery
Built confidence and pride in appearance
participants: young girls Bonika, Latarna, Tyereesa, Jonkia, Kayana

story_title: Operation Luna Success: 95% Reduction in At-Risk Youth
summary: Of the 21 young people originally referred by Operation Luna taskforce for being at-risk, only 1 remained on their case management list by December 2024, representing a 95% success rate in reducing anti-social behavior.
full_story_content: Of the 21 young people referred by Operation Luna, there was 1 young person remaining on their list as of July 2024 and from August to December 2024 of the 19 young people only 1 young person remained on the list. The majority of young people were removed from the Operation Luna taskforce case management list.
impact_highlights: 95% reduction in at-risk youth on Operation Luna list

summary: Despite 95% of participants having disengaged from school when the project started, 72% have now returned to school or alternative education pathways through Oonchiumpa's culturally-led support.
full_story_content: 95% of participants had disengaged from school when the Project started, since working with Oonchiumpa 72% have now returned to school or alternative education pathways. Teachers observed increased motivation and participation among students involved in the program. 3 young people who previously showed no interest in career development and employment are now asking about work and training to get work. One out of three eligible young people are applying for employment.
impact_highlights: Growing interest in employment and training
